pr_title: KOGITO-1553: [DMN Designer] Open a DMN file with an included model - Included Models tab

timeline.message:
KOGITO-1553: [DMN Designer] Open a DMN file with an included model - Included Models tab
KOGITO-1776: [DMN Designer] Create a "Load Projects From Client" button
KOGITO-1552: [DMN Designer] Open a DMN file with an included model - DRG Elements
Fixes an codestyle error and compatibility with Scesim.

timeline.bodyText: Should this block be removed? Considering: #3287.
timeline.author: karreiro

timeline.bodyText: I believe we can remove the non-used updateIDsWithAlias method as well.
timeline.author: karreiro

timeline.bodyText: Could we please add javadoc, especially the path, is it relative, absolute?
timeline.author: jomarko

replies.bodyText: It doesn't matter if it is relative or absolute. We just need the filename.
replies.author: danielzhe

timeline.bodyText:
Do I understand correctly all these methods works asynchronously?
What is the difference between those suffixed "Async" and those not suffixed
What is the reason somewhere we return Promise and somewhere we use Callback
timeline.author: jomarko

replies.bodyText:
Yes, they are async. I didn't know exactly how to differentiate one method from other, so I used the same pattern that I see in some C# projects (using "async" prefix to differentiate async from sync methods). I don't know if this is the best name here. I'm open to suggestions.


The difference is that the methods without "async" run synchronously and are not supported in Kogito, specially VSCode, because VSCode is multithread which lead to some issues that we don't have in singlethread environments like in Business Central. The root of all this is in Content API, that is asynchronous. So the main issue is when loading imported models during unmarshalling: I'm running a thread and I can continue only when the threads that load all the imported models are done. Which bring us to the question about Promise and Callback:


We're using callback when is not required to wait for some thread to finish. But Promise gives us the ability to call some code and continue the main flow only when that called code are finished. In other hand, with callbacks, the main flow doesn't wait for it to be finished.
replies.author: danielzhe

timeline.bodyText: Could you please explain combination of @dependent with @ApplicationScoped? For me the second one represnts singlotene per app while the first multiple instances available per app. I am not sure how we can combine them.
timeline.author: jomarko

timeline.bodyText:
Shouldn't we say the array size as we know it?
return promises
                    .all(fileLoadPromises.toArray(new Promise[fileLoadPromises.size()]))
                    .then(v -> promises.resolve(otherDefinitions));
timeline.author: jomarko

timeline.bodyText: Here we can use .orElse(Collections.emptyList()) as we are not manipulating with nodes afterwards.
timeline.author: jomarko

timeline.bodyText: Similar question as above . shouldn't we leverage known size of fileLoadPromises during new array creation?

timeline.bodyText: Could we please rename to sucessCallback or something more explicitely saying that is callback in case no issues during computation happened?
timeline.author: jomarko

timeline.bodyText: From my point of view in the default else branches it is more 'not supported' or 'illegal state'. because new comer can add his file into DMNClientModels class. In such case message about not found can be confusing. What do you think?
timeline.author: jomarko

timeline.bodyText: Could you please explain what effect has this 'something.dmn' value? I mean is that reflected somehow in UI or just the DMNClientModels.MODEL_WITH_IMPORTS is important?
timeline.author: jomarko

replies.bodyText: It can be anything. This method is just to load the test DMN models defined in DMNClientModels by the "Load Models From Client" button in our test project.
replies.author: danielzhe
